skill.name: datamol
skill.description: Pythonic wrapper around RDKit with simplified interface and sensible defaults. Preferred for standard drug discovery: SMILES parsing, standardization, descriptors, fingerprints, clustering, 3D conformers, parallel processing. Returns native rdkit.Chem.Mol objects. For advanced control or custom parameters, use rdkit directly.

security_audit.summary: This skill is documentation-only containing markdown files explaining the Datamol Python library. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or file system access. Pure instructional content for cheminformatics operations.

content.user_title: Work with molecular structures and drug discovery
content.value_statement: Analyzing molecular structures for drug discovery requires specialized cheminformatics tools. Datamol provides a simple Python interface to RDKit for parsing molecules, computing properties, generating 3D conformers, and finding similar compounds.
actual_capabilities: Parse and convert molecular formats (SMILES, SELFIES, InChI)
Compute molecular descriptors (MW, LogP, TPSA, HBD, HBA)
Generate molecular fingerprints for similarity calculations
Cluster molecules and select diverse subsets
Apply chemical reactions using SMARTS patterns
limitations: Requires Datamol and RDKit Python packages installed
Returns native RDKit molecule objects for advanced use

use_cases.title: Analyze compound libraries
use_cases.description: Filter drug-like molecules, compute properties, and identify similar compounds for lead optimization projects

use_cases.title: Prepare molecular datasets
use_cases.description: Convert chemical data to ML-ready formats, compute fingerprints, and create train/test splits by scaffold

use_cases.title: Study structure-activity
use_cases.description: Generate 3D conformers, analyze conformational diversity, and visualize SAR series with substructure highlighting

prompt_templates.title: Parse molecules
prompt_templates.prompt: Parse these SMILES strings to molecules using Datamol: CCO, c1ccccc1, CC(=O)O. Compute descriptors for each.

prompt_templates.title: Filter compounds
prompt_templates.prompt: Filter this list of molecules to keep only drug-like compounds using Lipinski rules: MW under 500, LogP under 5, HBD under 5, HBA under 10.

prompt_templates.title: Find similar molecules
prompt_templates.prompt: Find the 10 most similar molecules to this query molecule using Tanimoto similarity with ECFP4 fingerprints.

prompt_templates.title: Generate 3D structures
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate 50 3D conformers for this molecule using ETKDGv3, apply RMS cutoff of 0.5 Angstrom, and cluster by RMSD.

output_examples.input: Parse aspirin (CC(=O)Oc1ccccc1C(=O)O), compute all descriptors, and find similar molecules in this library
output: Top 5 similar compounds identified with Tanimoto similarity > 0.7

best_practices: Always standardize molecules from external sources before analysis
Use parallel processing (n_jobs=-1) for large compound libraries
Check for None values after parsing SMILES strings
Filter molecules early using drug-likeness rules to reduce computational load
anti_patterns: Skipping molecule standardization on imported compound data
Using Butina clustering on datasets larger than 1000 molecules
Ignoring stereochemistry when it matters for activity
Processing all conformers without RMS filtering for large datasets

faq.question: What is the difference between Datamol and RDKit?
faq.answer: Datamol is a Pythonic wrapper around RDKit with simplified defaults. Use Datamol for common tasks. Use RDKit directly for advanced control.

faq.question: How many molecules can I process efficiently?
faq.answer: Datamol handles thousands of molecules. For clustering, limit to ~1000 due to full distance matrix. Use diversity selection for larger sets.

faq.question: Does this skill work with cloud storage?
faq.answer: Yes, Datamol uses fsspec to read/write files from S3, GCS, Azure, and HTTP. Requires additional cloud library installation.

faq.question: Is my molecular data safe?
faq.answer: Datamol runs locally. All computations happen on your machine. No data is sent to external servers unless you explicitly upload files.

faq.question: Why are some molecules returning None?
faq.answer: Invalid SMILES or parsing errors cause None returns. Always check for None and use standardize_mol to fix common issues.

faq.question: Can I use this with machine learning frameworks?
faq.answer: Yes, convert molecules to fingerprints or descriptors, then use with scikit-learn, PyTorch, or TensorFlow for QSAR models.
